identificationModule.briefTitle: A Comparative Clinical Study to Assess Pain Score and Wound Healing Following Fractional Ablation With a DFG Laser and CO2 Laser
identificationModule.officialTitle: A Comparative Clinical Study to Assess Pain Score and Wound Healing Following Fractional Ablation With a Difference Frequency Generation (DFG) Laser and Carbon Dioxide (CO2) Laser

descriptionModule.briefSummary: This research study aims assess whether the Difference Frequency Generation (DFG) laser could be a better alternative to the CO2 laser in terms of reduced side effects and patient downtime.
descriptionModule.detailedDescription:
The primary goal of this study is to compare the pain score and wound healing time in healthy subjects undergoing low fluence fractional ablation using the DFG and CO2 lasers. The secondary objective involves assessing the impact of each laser on dermal vasculature using an Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) imaging system.

Participants will be treated with the DFG and CO2 laser to the inner forearms. Photography, pain scores, and OCT imaging will be recorded over the course of the study visits.

The investigators plan to enroll 23 healthy subjects to complete the study. Subjects must be equal to greater than 18 years old and may be any gender or Fitzpatrick skin type.

armGroups.label: Treatment
armGroups.description: 23 healthy subjects with treatment of the DFG and CO2 laser

interventions.name: DFG Laser
interventions.description: Laser treatment to the inner forearm

interventions.name: CO2 Laser
interventions.description: Laser treatment to the inner forearm

interventions.name: Optical coherence tomography (OCT)
interventions.description: Angiographic OCT imaging at areas of interest

primaryOutcomes.description: Subjects will report pain score using VAS for the CO2 and DFG laser treated areas at Visit 1. The VAS is a 10cm long scale with 0mm representing "no pain" and 100mm representing "worst possible pain".
Wound healing of the laser treated areas will be assessed and compared via photography at each visit.

secondaryOutcomes.description: The OCT system will be used to assess re-epithelialization and dermal vasculature of laser treated areas at each visit
The OCT system will be used to assess re-epithelialization and dermal vasculature of laser treated areas at each visit
